supporting_text: The One Health cooperation, which intends to prevent the transmission of resistant bacteria from animals, the environment and food to humans, is highly prioritised by the current government.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including three measurable goals for antibiotic consumption in humans.
Denmark was the first in the world to establish a One Health national monitoring programme for humans and animals in 1995.
The One Health cooperation intends to prevent the transmission of resistant bacteria from animals, the environment and food to humans.
The One Health cooperation intends to prevent the transmission of resistant bacteria from animals, the environment and food to humans.
The working group for the follow-up of the national goals will meet biannually, and initiatives will be monitored annually in order to follow the progress in achieving the goals.
The three measurable goals aim at reducing the consumption of antibiotics among humans by the year 2020.
The consumption of critically important antibiotics should be reduced by 10 % by 2020 measured by DDD/100 bed-days for hospitalised patients.
A total of 35 million DKK was earmarked for the establishment of national Learning and Quality Team from 2015 to 2018.
The document does not specify an assessment of future budget requirements.
The structure of the National Antibiotic Council was strengthened in 2017, as defined in the Council's new mandate.
The Danish Health Authority's 'Guidelines for prescribing antibiotics' from 2012 present a general set of rules for antibiotic prescription.
National antibiotic public awareness campaigns have been carried out to spread information and change public attitudes regarding antibiotic use.
National and local antibiotic awareness campaigns are launched each year to help ensure that members of the public receive knowledge about why antibiotics should only be prescribed when necessary.
Denmark's participation in international networks is mentioned as part of the One Health strategy.
The Danish Health Data Authority follows the development of physicians' use of specific indication codes for antibiotic prescriptions.
The document does not specify actions related to developing capacity for newly emerged resistance.
Systematic cleaning and good (hand) hygiene are considered essential factors in the prevention of hospital-acquired infections.
The Danish Health Authority's guidelines for prescribing antibiotics are based on international standards.
The Danish Health Authority's 'Guidelines for prescribing antibiotics' present rules for antibiotic prescription.
The Danish Health Authority aims at restricting indications for use of antibiotics and increasing the use of antibiotics that are less likely to lead to the development of resistance.
The document does not specify participation in international collaborative research.
